title: Who we are
text:
Partners

Web Hosting: Deutsches Bergbau-Museum Bochum  The Deutsches Bergbau-Museum Bochum – founded in 1930 – is one of eight research museums belonging to the Leibniz Association. It researches, teaches and preserves the history of the mining, processing and use of geo-resources across all of the relevant time periods. Its research areas include: archaeometallurgy, mining history, materials science, and mining archaeology, together with the research laboratory, and the Montanhistorische Dokumentationszentrum.
DMT-Gesellschaft für Lehre und Bildung mbH  DMT-Gesellschaft für Lehre und Bildung mbH (DMT-LB), based in Bochum, is a collective association of the German coal mining industry and acts as the funding organisation of Deutsches Bergbau-Museum Bochum (German Mining Museum) and Technische Hochschule Georg Agricola. It was established as the Westfälische Berggewerkschaftskasse (WBK) in 1864 and merged with the Steinkohlen-Bergbau-Verein (Stbv) and Bergbau Forschung GmbH under the auspices of DeutscheMontanTechnologie e.V. (DMT) in 1990.

title: Hello, world!
text: GlobaLID is constantly growing but until now there was no single point of access for all resources of GlobaLID. Moreover, the web application as the most important product so far does look nice on small screens and mobile devices. Therefore, this page was set up. Have a look around and explore what GlobaLID already has to offer, what is planned and how you can become part of it.

title: GlobaLID
text:
The GlobaLID (Global Lead Isotope Database) project aims to develop next-generation tools for working with lead isotope data in the archaeological sciences. The primary aim is to create an infrastructure for the submission and provision of lead isotope reference data that makes it easy to submit data to the database, minimises data curation efforts by automatised checks and enrichment of metadata from other sources, and by providing easy access to the data through a web application or the database API. Data will be handled in accordance with the FAIR principles to maximise their findability, accessibility, interoperability and reusability.
Development of this infrastructure is done in close discussion with and active support from the community to ensure that the products are close to the community’s needs. Prototypes of the database and web application were released in 2021 and the project presented to the public in 2022. The next big step will be the development of a FAIR metadata scheme for lead isotope data in the archaeological sciences. This will not only massively improve the compatibility of lead isotope data but will also serve as data model for the full version of the database. In parallel it is aimed to increase the coverage of the database and to improve the web application.
The development of Being currently an unfunded side-project, progress relies entirely on the strong commitment of the team. Being an open project, we are always open for new members. If you are interested in helping GlobaLID to develop and make our vision come true, please reach out to the core team via mail.



GlobaLID consists of three products and more might be developed as the project evolves.

Database (most recent version | archive)
Web application (live version | source code)
Educational materials (in development as an NFDI4Earth Educational Pilot).




GlobaLID was officially presented to the public in the article “From OXALID to GlobaLID: Introducing a modern and FAIR lead isotope database with an interactive application” in the journal Archaeometry (doi:10.1111/arcm.12762). The database was published as dataset with an extensive description of its structure in the repository of the GFZ Data Services (doi:10.5880/fidgeo.2021.031). The features of the web application prototype are presented in our video tutorial on YouTube. You can learn more about the different products and how to use them at their respective pages.
